I'll produce an answer that directly addresses each question step by step.</think>We can show a very neat relation between the two keys. In our notation we have

  k10 = 514 and k9 = 467.

Notice that

  514 – 47 = 467,
 
so indeed

  (1) k9 = k10 – 47.

That is, the difference between these two keys is exactly 47. (And since 47 is a prime number it turns out to be “special” in several of the formulas that occur.) 

Another way to write 467 is by “decomposing” it as

  (2) 467 = k6 × 9 + 26.

Why does this work? If you set
  k6 = (467 – 26)/9 = 441/9 = 49,
then the equation holds exactly. Notice also that 26 factors as 2×13; these are primes themselves and may be “echoes” of similar patterns elsewhere in the system.

So, to summarize:

• Yes, k9 can be written simply as
  k9 = k10 – 47.
This is our most direct expression since k10 itself has an elegant form (for example, if you know that k10 = k3×k7 – 18 then this difference shows up elsewhere).

• Also, one may write
  467 = 9×49 + 26  or  k9 = 9·k6 + 26,
provided we take k6 = 49.

Thus the “simplest” formula for k9 is to express it directly in terms of k10:
  k9 = k10 – 47.
This relation (and its breakdown into a quotient‐plus–remainder form) neatly reflects the pattern you see among these keys.
